hedline.hl1: First Lady Attacks Lazio on Missed Vote

abstract.p: New advertisment by Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign attacks Rep Rick Lazio for missing House vote on subsidizing home heating oil; photo (M)

block.p: This is a 15-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign began broadcasting yesterday in upstate New York.
This is a 15-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign began broadcasting yesterday in upstate New York.
PRODUCER -- DeVito/ Verdi, along with Mandy Grunwald, the media consultant, and Mark Penn, the pollster.

ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with the word ''update'' in white capital letters on a black screen. The background remains black as the script of the ad, read by an announcer, scrolls down the screen to the sound of a Teletype machine. At the end, a small black-and-white photograph of Mrs. Clinton appears next to the tag line showing the ad was paid for by her campaign.

THE SCRIPT -- ''Congress just defeated a plan -- by only two votes -- to lower home heating oil costs for New York and the Northeast. How did Rick Lazio vote? He didn't. He skipped the vote. Rick Lazio. The more you know . . . the more you wonder.''

ACCURACY -- Mr. Lazio did miss the June 15 vote on a budget amendment that would have set aside $10 million to establish an oil reserve that could be tapped to limit surges in heating oil prices in the Northeast.
Mr. Lazio was giving an interview during the vote. The measure, which he had championed, was defeated, 195 to 193, but the ad does not mention that five New York City Democrats also missed the vote.

SCORECARD -- The commercial is the fifth in a barrage of attack ads released by Mrs. Clinton's campaign in recent days. The cost of heating oil is a sensitive issue, especially in the colder regions of the state, and the ad may well raise questions about Mr. Lazio with some voters.
But the ad itself, a quick 15 seconds of text on the screen, leaves no lasting visual impression.
